theory.introduction: Variables are like containers that hold data. You use them to store values and use them later in your code.
theory.explanation: In Python, you don't need to declare the type of a variable. You just assign a value using the equals sign `=`. Once assigned, you can use the variable name to refer to the value stored inside it.
keyPoints: Variables are created when you assign a value using `=`
Variable names must start with a letter or underscore
Python is dynamically typed ‚Äî no need to declare types
Variables can hold numbers, text, or any data type

codeExamples.explanation: This creates a variable called `name` and prints its value
You can store numbers in variables and use them in expressions

importantNotes: ‚ùå You can't use spaces or symbols in variable names
